job_title: Professor Outside the Tenure Systems in Waltham, MA
pros: Good benefits- health insurance is good. Contract faculty can serve on major committees and be treated (and given service obligations) that look to the outside like normal tenure-track work. So, it's nice that in this way you are not held back and made to only teach.
cons:
Contract (=non-tenure-track) faculty are a high portion of the overall full-time faculty – some estimates are 50%. But contact faculty are treated like lesser beings than their tenure-track colleagues – spoken to like children, paid far less, and often asked to do high levels of service far beyond job descriptions that mostly involve teaching. It's a recipe for exploitation when you have a two-tiered system like this, with tenured faculty able to grossly misbehave with little consequences and near-total job security, while contract faculty have to say yes to everything so they will be rehired. Note that job titles make it not obvious from the outside who is tenure-track and who is contract – both are called 'Assistant Professor', 'Associate Professor', and 'Professor' on places like the public-facing faculty guide. This obscures just how many regular, full-time faculty are not tenure-track and being paid less and asked to do more for their work - and often working with little respect from their tenure(-track) colleagues.

Faculty and staff pay alike is much lower here than at many other Boston area schools, so we are hemorrhaging employees at this point – especially staff – who are often not replaced. Those who stay often do so out of goodwill or some historical connection, but increasingly many of them are leaving too. It's a mess.

pros:
- Relatively small university, pretty laid back attitude, lots of 'perks' are allowed such as 'side projects' or attending talks/courses of (personal) interest

- Some faculties are (very) open for graduate student feedback on how to improve the quality of their services
cons:
- Not having formal employee status results in 'challenges' in filing taxes / dealing with IRS. You can expect no support from the university if e.g. you are audited and the numbers don't add up

- Some (but not all) grad students get paid only 10 months per year, but are expected to work 12 months, including holidays

- Instead of doing their work and teach courses, or hire more tenured faculty, faculty prefers to defer teaching to adjunct professors on temp contracts. They don't always do the best possible job, causing trouble 'down the road' (long after the adjunct has left)

- The CEO's main role seems to be to hire all his friends as vice president or provost of something. It's not that the university is growing, it's just that the ratio of C*O and support staff to faculty is increasing. But this seems to be the norm at other universities as well

review_title: Great place to be a lecturer in philosophy
pros:
Highly motivated, quirky students, fun to teach.
Generally welcoming, collegial community, with a vibrant intellectual life.
Good benefits, reasonable pay.
Great opportunities to develop new courses.
cons:
Lots of turnover in upper administration, leading to a lot of stinginess regarding faculty hires.  
It is doubtful whether there will be permanent positions in philosophy any time in the near future.

review_title: Beautiful campus.  Nice people.  Low pay, but solid benefits.
pros: Beautiful campus with lots of great people to work with.  Gorgeous art work everywhere you look.  I learned a lot while at my job.
cons:
Limited personal growth.  Things happen at a very slow pace.  My manager was not supportive a great deal of the time. A couple of examples:  When I told my manager that I was giving my notice, (I gave the standard 2 weeks) she actually asked me if I had lied to get my new position. 
She also told me during an employee review that she wanted to rate me as superior, but that she did not because she believed that no one in her opinion was deserving of a superior review.  As a result, I did not get much of a raise that year.

pros: I was able to work while getting my degree, which was extremely helpful--even just a dozen or so  hours a week paid for groceries and textbooks (everything that didn't come on the bill from the university, basically). My managers were conscious of the fact that I'm a student and therefore might need to change my schedule based on exams and would go home for breaks. I'll be graduating with four years of work with the same department, demonstrated increased responsibility over time, and demonstrated office skills.
cons: No guaranteed student positions for work-study students. There doesn't seem to be much centralized training for how to deal with student workers, so it's spotty depending on what department how much responsibility you have or whether your hourly rate goes up with seniority--that kind of thing.

pros: Like, I could be sitting around *not* making $12/hr, but instead I get to have enough money for groceries. I like groceries. And not starving. So I'd say it's a pretty sweet ride.
cons: They really need to replace the Student Activities Jeep. Like I'm pretty sure the play in the steering wheel is getting worse every day. Pretty soon we'll turn and turn but the Jeep will just continue straight despite our best efforts, rolling us into a non-negotiable and inexorable doom.

pros: Small school environment with high-profile research labs.  Most all PIs and lab personnel are willing and even eager to share equipment and supplies.  Collegial and not a competitive environment, distinct from some other Boston area institutions.
cons:
Smaller size results in less abundant equipment and necessitates more shared facilities.  Large premium on space for labs and classrooms.  Lacking some necessary and state of the art equipment in shared facilities (e.g. accessible two-photon microscope).  
University places tremendous value on teaching but actions don't support that assertion.

job_title: ESL and Writing Tutor and Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: It is a reputable university in the Greater Boston area, has a very nice campus, puts good facilities at one's disposal, and offers a rich, multicultural, friendly community to work in.
cons: NOTE: I was a graduate student, teaching ESL classes, writing classes and being a teaching assistant. I was NOT an administrative employee. For my kind of work, the remuneration per hour is about double the state minimum wage. Not by any means a bad offer in this economy, but people make much more for the same work in a non-university set-up. Given the fees students pay (very high) and the salary senior admin take home (also very high), certainly more funds could be redirected towards people who do a lot of the actual work with the students.

review_title: Good if you want stability but so-so for career opportunities
pros: Stable, flexible work environment, paid time off over Christmas break. I am a working parent and the work environment here is very conducive to my family responsibilities. They were also great about welcoming me back to work after an extended leave at home with my children. People here are great and is part of the reason why work is enjoyable.
cons: Low pay and low raises, few opportunities for advancement. People often stay in their same position for 15+ years! Depending on department you work in, they like to hire people with advanced degrees (MS or higher) but do not pay commensurate with the level of experience and education.

review_title: Comfortable work environment with cheerful supervisor, low-stress responsibilities
pros: The position I held was a work-study job as a secretary. The head administrative personal were understanding when scheduling hours and worked around classes. The professors and students I interacting with were, by and large, respectful and not overly demanding. Perhaps the best part of the work environment was being able to study or read in the office, as there were few times where the office was incredibly busy.
cons: As I was an undergrad in a work study job, pay was understandably low. There were rumors in upper management about layoffs, but students obviously did not expect to stay more than a few semesters in their positions.

review_title: Great place for life sciences Ph.D. graduate students
pros: There is a lot of collaboration among labs at the school, and the community is very sharing and relaxed. The stipend they give you is competitive with other school nearby, and if you are accepted into the program, that stipend is guaranteed.
cons: The shared resources available are not very competitive with some of the nearby schools, but there is still core facilities to help you with research. There is also some disorganization with sharing vital administrative information, but if you seek it out, they'll help with a smile.

pros: Good education and many research opportunities.  A lot of good research going on.  The school is large enough to be very good in their specialized research fields, but small enough so that it's easy to have personal contact with professors.  Very interdisciplinary.
cons: The upper administration did not appear to show the greatest consideration for the students during my time here with the closing of the Rose and making measure changes without involving the students.  The physics department was good, though.

review_title: i was a server at Brendais university, serving students with respect and properly.
pros: seeking to obtain a part-time or full-time position in an organization where i can grow professionally and further enhance my skills, knowlege and experience to face and overcome the challenges of today.
cons: the challenges of today's changing work environment and to apple the knowlege that i have accumulated from past professional experiences.

pros: Great place to work. Access to prominent journalists, work on interesting cases and have a real impact. Got to see the world though a whole new lens, learned about important issues and investigated real problems. Big resume booster, too! Free food regularly too, as a benefit.
cons: Honestly, I have very few, if any, complaints. I really liked working at Schuster. Everyone is very committed and focused on what they're doing.

pros: The university offers its employees a lot of perks and time off.  They are forward thinking in terms of personal development and willing to work with you to get to where you would like to be.
cons:
Most people have been at the organization for years and are very politically charged.  Unfortunately Brandeis has gone through a lot of transitions in its efforts to stream line things such as forced retirement of people who's been with the university over 10 years and over the age of 60.  

Its senior management is filled with people who understand its needs and not.

review_title: Awesome environment to live with as a grad student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros:
- People at Brandeis, from students to faculties and stuff are very friendly, welcoming and willing to help when needed. I joined Brandeis in 2011, and it was my first time in the USA. I really enjoyed how everybody was willing to help in various fields, from housing to course work.
- At Brandeis, there is strong inter-departmental collaboration. You will find that most of research projects are joint-projects either Physics-Chemistry, Computer-Physics, Biology-Physics, Computer-Neuroscience, ....
- Awesome facilities to carry on experiments
cons:
- Few places to find diversified food
- Old buildings. So, my suggestion is to find an off campus housing

review_title: I've seen better, I've seen worst
pros:
The university makes true attempts to treat employees and recognize their work
Pleasant working environment: nice people, pleasant outdoors, OK plus offices, eateries, etc.
cons: Some key benefits are missing (free T-passes - the place is accessible via public transportation but not easily not cheaply). Some benefits are hyped - like, don't really trust their emergency medical service.

pros: Wonderful culture, great colleagues who are passionate and care about what they are doing. Great benefits and great work-life balance.
cons: Come in at the salary that will make you happy for the long term-  annual raise scale caps out at a low amount, so that even stellar performers do not see much of an annual wage increase.

pros:
If you are in the field of education, you will love our students.  They are intelligent, passionate, and driven.  This comes along with high anxiety and no fear of challenging your ideas, but that is the challenge and support of education professionals.  
Many staff and faculty here are excellent.  Things are changing for the good.
cons: Rare opportunities for mobility.  Change, although needed, still creates divide and challenges -- either evolve or move on.

review_title: Postdoctoral opportunities in Biology at Brandeis University
pros: For people driving there is enough parking and it is a pretty easy commute. It has a beautiful campus. There are some teaching and mentoring opportunities. Also there is a good variety of instruments within the department.
cons: Keep in mind that the pros and cons will depend on which laboratory you joined. In my case I experience verbal and emotional abuse from the principal investigator as well as some very uncomfortable moments that made me question if it was sexual harassment. There was no respect in the laboratory and people where so stressed that the environment was tense most of the time.

pros:
I received a great deal of training while in my role at Brandeis and in addition to that as a full-time exempt staffer you can take one class a semester for free if the class is related to your work which is an incredible perk. 

The work day schedule is pretty flexible and the people you work with are first rate for the most part. 

The campus is very scenic and it's great to walk around.

There's an annual raise typically between 1-3% of your salary.
cons:
Promotions and raises are hard to come across without a masters or doctorate degree. 

Departments are sometimes unwilling to collaborate with each other, also for research staff departments are resistant to enabling researchers to teach in the department of their field regardless of them already working in research at the university. 

There are not annual reviews of every staff member, staff would benefit greatly from receiving clear constructive feedback from their supervisors and those they supervise.

pros: Wonderful students and student workers. Top notch faculty. Pleasant campus. Accessible to public transit via commuter rail. Ample employee parking. Used to have good retirement plan.
cons: In Library / IT merged department, significant problems. Though some issues come with change in economy and overall financial woes of university, much could have been done to ease the burden on staff through considerate communication and competent planning.

pros: Top notch science research. Informal environment. Interdisciplinary collaborations between fields is facilitated.
cons: It's in Waltham, so you have to take the commuter rail. It's small relative to Harvard, so it can't be good at everything, so it's specialized in certain areas of research. Very good within specialties, though.

review_title: Adjunct Faculty Enjoys Contribution to Student's Growth
pros: Having been part of the GPS faculty since the beginning (15+ yrs), I have grown as much as the students and I enjoy very much watching them grow right in front of my eyes over the course of a Term.  It is not unusual that students are developing their 'voice' an important attribute to have as we move forward in our professional and personal life.
cons: Funny the review can't be submitted without cons yet I don't really have any.

review_title: A good place to work, with good research and teaching opportunities.
pros: Strong research and teaching opportunities.  Self-directed environment.  Group of bright and interested faculty and staff and strong students.  Opportunity to build a strong teaching portfolio.  Outsized research opportunities given the size of the school and proximity to and relationships with other schools in nearby Boston offer numerous collaboration opportunities.
cons: Some administration missteps in recent years that drew press attention and objections from faculty and staff.  Not a great deal of intellectual or political/ideological diversity.

review_title: Excellent preparation for a career in the film industry
pros:
- Desired work hours are taken into serious consideration.
- You can receive training in the use of very advanced cameras and other film equipment.
- Manager is very responsive, dedicated, and easy to talk to.
cons:
- You must be a student to work there, and Brandeis isn't for everyone...
- Don't expect to make a ton of money, the primary benefit here is experience.

review_title: Nice place to work, but no effective use of resources.
job_title: Help Desk Technician in Waltham, MA
pros: I worked at helpdesk, the job was pretty good and the clients are nicer than you will find in typical customer support job. The school itself has great academics.
cons: I think University does not use the funds efficiently, a lot of money is wasted on unnecessary things, that could be invested in expanding the school. Sadly not a lot of companies recruit on campus.

pros: I find respect and support when I work here. I think that this is a great place to work if you care about the people surrounding you.
cons: The only downside of working  at Brandeis is salary that looks a bit on the low side. The rest seems to be fine.

pros: More relaxed atmosphere than corporate world; good benefits; work-life balance is easy to maintain, discounted education for children, and free education to full-time employees (exclusions apply); generous vacations
cons: extremely bureaucratic; low salaries; most people work 9 to 5 and don't really care about the job being done; very little challenge

pros: Brandeis pays reasonably well for adjunct work, largely due to the part-time faculty union, which is strong. The location is good, close to Boston. The campus is modern and has good facilities and resources. Adjunct faculty in my departments (history and the University Writing Program) get offices.
cons: Brandeis could be friendlier and more collegial for adjuncts  - it is a competitive place and people tend to be very focused on work.

review_title: Terrific place to work with a highly supportive staff.
pros: Very satisfied with my experience there and felt that there were significant opportunities for growth.  Brandeis' benefits are strong for a university, with flexible summer schedules, time off and health benefits.
cons: The biggest challenge was that I worked there during the economic downturn with impacted the University.  There was a lot of budget cutting in each department and a lower morale on campus.

review_title: Good place to launch your career
pros: If you are someone interested in innovation in higher ed, there is a willingness to try new initiatives and there are few barriers to getting things started
cons: Staff consistently are treated as second-class citizens (faculty are treated like royalty) and there are very few ways to advance in your career.

pros: The faculty is great: very sociable and willing to mentor. The pay is pretty good as far as teaching assistant salaries go.
cons: The department is pretty small, which can be a con when it comes to the number and variety of classes offered. There doesn't seem to be much actual student-faculty research going on. Faculty are good mentors but should push internships / personal projects more.

review_title: Decent place to do PhD is very self motivated
pros: 1. Very interdisciplinary 2. Interesting research. 3. Some (not all labs) have good life work balance. 4. Good location.
cons: 1. Very little tools for PI student mediation. 2. Very poor statement/enforcement degree requirements. 3. Relatively low diversity (with respect to some groups). 4. Some labs have very bad work life balance.

pros: The school is looking to expand and open new departments which had led to an uptick in morale. The school is still focused on the sciences, while the more artsy fields are not as regarded.
cons: Expansion projects eat up a lot of the budget so wages are stagnating. A lot of political correctness on campus and among the team leads to a 'forced' environment.

pros: Meet new students early, work with sustainability leaders on campus, free housing and meals, attend whatever orientation events you want
cons: Have to be at school a day before orientation starts for training, cuts your break short, a lot of time spent sitting around with nothing to do.

pros: In general the staff are pleasant and as long as the assigned work is completed, then they  allow one a flexible work schedule. The work is engaging but when funding drops out then hours can be cut if there is not enough coverage.Typical for academia, though.
cons: Work was interesting but pay was not particularly competitive.

pros:
- cutting edge research
- new buildings going up
- friendly coworkers
- many on-campus events and activities
- university tries hard to generate good morale
cons:
- parking situation is very tight
- have to cross very busy street to get to campus
- buildings not taken care of very well 
- buildings should be cleaned more

review_title: Great experience overall, it was an internship in the financial affairs and treasury department
job_title: Financial Affairs and Treasury Intern in Waltham, MA
pros: Great people, great location, great experience in the different departments with a variety of different people.  Great internship experience and the people there made accounting more enjoyable for me.  It really helped me out along the way to get me where I am today.
cons: Nothing it was a pleasure working there.

pros: Excellent Work and Life Balance for employees and good amount of time off.  Manager is wonderful and allows for lots of flexibility as long as the job gets done.  Students are great to work with
cons:
Pay scale of administrators compared to faculty
Commute is long
Department is understaffed

pros: There were lots of opportunities to collaborate. Also good mentorship is available for researchers, particularly in research methods and statistical programming. Training opportunities also available.
cons: There is always more work than there is time to do it all. It can be difficult to maintain a work-life balance, although management is at least verbally in support of trying to do so.

job_title: Post Doc Researcher, Biology in Waltham, MA
pros:
Nice atmosphere, collegiate feeling.  Good size, so it feels like there is a community.
Campus is quite nice
cons:
As a postdoc typical postdoc issues apply.
Location is annoying if you live in Boston.  They could easily do small things to make things better, like subsidising commuter rail passes (which most other Boston area universities do).
Food on campus is appalling.

review_title: It is acceptable for on-campus job
pros: So the work-load is not so bad since Brandeis University is not a large public school. And most students in the school are pretty smart so being a TA does not mean that all of my time will be used in answering stupid questions. Instead, most of the questions I met were pretty insightful.
cons: The pay is below average.

pros: The quality of people I work with is great.  The culture is friendly and collaborative.  The new research facilities are good, but Brandeis does not have a resources of a large research institution.
cons: Brandeis does not have the resources of a large research institution, so some "core" groups may be missing, and some equipment is outdated.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros:
- Many opportunities for students to find work and gain experience at a biology lab on campus 
- PI and supervisor very encouraging and want students to do well & learn
cons: - Depending on the lab and PI, you may have to be assertive to get more complicated research work and not be stuck doing menial tasks

job_title: LTS Help Desk Technician in Waltham, MA
pros:
Flexible hours
Friendly, engaging environment
Learn a lot on the job
Get to work with various departments within LTS as well as various Brandeis community members
cons:
Some workers do nothing and slip through the cracks
Some managers are better than others
Some may find it to be overly casual

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Waltham, MA
pros: Brandeis generally allows for a flexible work schedule which is great for working parents or people with elderly parents. I found that the people are very friendly and collegial.
cons: The biggest drawback is that there is not a consistent career path. Career development of subordinates does not seem to be a priority for managers.

pros: Good Benefits, Matching 403b, health, etc. Good commuting location. Very active in the community, Social Justice very high priority.
cons: Top heavy administration, inequity in pay from top level staff, administration, faculty, to lower level and part time employees.

pros: Great staff, wonderful students, and the faculty are generally a lot less entitled than faculty tend to be elsewhere.
cons: The top-level management is terrible across the board. Groups like IT are short-staffed and mismanaged to death, and there's total disconnect between the top-tier administration and the staff. Good employees are leaving, and the loss includes both institutional knowledge and great skills.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Waltham, MA
pros:
The staff at Brandeis Library trust you and give you a lot of independence. 
The shifts are consistent, but they understand you are a college student and school is important.
cons:
The work can definitely be fairly boring. 
A lot of people seem to clash with the full-time staff, but I never had that experience.

pros:
Supportive faculty 
Collaborative 
Great research environment 
Eager students 
Good seminars by outside speakers
Don't have to commute into the city
cons: Conditions are improving for postdoctoral fellows, but they still should get better benefits and be paid NIH guideline salary. The options for food on campus are still lacking compared to other campuses.

review_title: Great organization, great people, compensation can use more attention.
pros: Benefits are a plus at this organization. Especially retirement and continuing education. A partial cell phone stipend also exists, though it should be expanded a bit.
cons: The workload is often heavy. Calls for more staff resources often go unheeded and compensation can be hard to improve.

pros: Not to much to write about.
cons: upper management will not tell you anything, and are VERY 2 faced (if you see them).

review_title: Brandeis University is an accessible, welcoming small university.
job_title: Office of Development in Waltham, MA
pros:
Nancy Winship, Senior VP of Institutional Advancement, is extremely dedicated to Brandeis and to her staff.  
Staff and administration are accessible and easy to work with on the whole.
Campus is an accessible size.
cons: Salaries tend to be lower as compared with other Boston-area colleges and universities.

pros:
--Matching contribution is an amazing benefit, particularly once you move to private sector companies
--Decent vacation policy with PTO increase after certain number of years
--Ability to take classes
cons:
--Flexibility with work-life depends on your manager
--Some roles have no possible growth channels

pros: supportive workplace atmosphere among senior staff, employees, department heads and students. Provided a positive work life balance.
cons: staff for several departments and centers have unique job responsibilities and hr salaries and job postings should reflect this more accurately. Not all positions are a one size fits all model.

job_title: Student Web Developer in Waltham, MA
pros: Convenience is the best reason to work at Brandeis University when you're a student. I work and take classes in the same building!
cons: Diverse learning is limited and focused, as in most jobs, and so the amount of diversity in the experience you gain is limited as well, but this is expected.

review_title: Workload for a Teaching Assistant will depend upon the Professor and your Students
pros: -Get to teach students who are passionate about the same topics as you
cons:
-Have to teach students who may not care about the course material
-The amount of work that you will be responsible for will depend upon how organized the professor is

review_title: Steady and Solid but no growth potential
pros: great team, community, external benefits like swim classes for kids, CSA
cons: no professional development opportunities (left up to employee) - what is offered through HR is outsourced and lacking; University slow to promote

job_title: Office of High School Programs in Waltham, MA
pros: Great hours (7 hour days), use of gym, wonderful student population, small campus, great work-life balance
cons: New managers were not trained in the "Office of High School Programs"

pros: As a student worker, my supervisors were great and the office I worked in was very interested in helping me grow as a student.
cons: Lots of outside politics always entering the work environment. Sometimes it distracts from the work you're doing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: Brandeis is a small wonderful university. It infuses all academic work with sense for social justice. People are friendly and cooperative. It has both the advantages of a small liberal arts school and a research university.
cons: If you like fast-paced environments this is not a place for you.

review_title: experience may vary from lab to lab
pros:
nice supporting staff
beautiful campus
relative good work-life balance
nice library
cons:
poor colleague support
lab disorganized and uncomfortable
weak career support  training
professor unapproachable and don't really care about trainee's well being
very few food options on campus
not 401k available for postdoc

pros: if you like to be totally independent, you are not in a rush to publish and likes being in a high competitive environment, go for it!
cons: salary is really low, I didn´t have any increased on my salary at any moment, you have zero benefits, no package benefit, no visa paper work covered

pros: Higher than average pay for a campus job. Flexible hours that match your study schedule. Easy to reach out to students about learning opportunities.
cons: Limited hours. Sometimes it gets hectic and overwhelming when too many people come to office hours at the same time.

review_title: Brandeis is a great place for a postdoc
pros: My PI was amazing. She was always willing to help and had great suggestions. she made me a better scientist.
cons: campus can be a bit of a bore.

pros: Most of faculty members are energetic and efficient. School staff are very nice. Location is great in boston area, very close to highway 90 and 95.
cons: School is small, not enough parking place. Dorm is really crowded. Some faculty members are really mean to international students.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Waltham, MA
pros:
Small school often means significant attention from advisors (though this can vary by department and how they are funded). 

Intellectual Community
cons:
Pay is decent but doesn't keep up with cost of living. Boston area is exceptionally expensive.
Food options on campus are limited
No vision or dental covered in health insurance.

job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Waltham, MA
pros: Small liberal arts college with a strong mission of social justice.  Staff are able to take classes at the university and earn master's degrees.
cons: Smaller school; salaries are not as competitive as the larger universities in the area.

pros: Beautiful campus with lots of very smart faculty who are easy to access and invested in pushing your career forward.
cons:
Far from the Harvard/MIT network.  Collaboration is difficult. 
Using the commuter rail is so unreliable

pros: It was an excellent work environment.  The coworkers and managers were very suportive.  Also the acdemic environment was very stimulation.  Overall it was a wonderful work experience.
cons: i did not find anything negative in the work environment.

pros: The staff are talented and truly care about each other.
cons: Lots of management turn over the past 7 yrs has led to a complete disconnect between the C-level suite and the rest of IT.

pros:
-Independent working conditions
-Free coffee and snacks
-Great connects with professional staff 
-Important cause, intrinsic motivation to work
cons: -Sometimes projects feel a little bit aimless

pros:
-Some of the people who work there genuinely want to be there and do good work.
-Time Off was was generous but changes are being made to reduce number of days off
cons:
- 0 flexibility for some with regards to work life balance. NO telecommuting 
-There are many incompetent and ill-qualified people at the top.
- Pay is severely under market range
-Many people are doing the work 2-3 people

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: I loved helping students learn. The pay depends on the department, but it allows you to have really great connections with a professor.
cons: Some professors are very disorganized. Make sure you TA with a professor who you know will make use of you.

review_title: A student and a teaching assistant. Very low pay as a TA, otherwise Brandies has a nice culture.
pros: Nice campus, flexible hours, if the professor is nice you can have a good time.
cons: Pay is very low, no benefits.

pros:
Good employer to work for, especially in the ECON or BUS department.
Making good connections.
Resume.
cons:
Students can sometimes be little annoying, but that is to be expected.
Pay is hardly competitive.
Sometimes unpredictable hours.

pros:
- Lenient management and staff
- Highly flexible hours and conditions
- Promotions are possible, depends on you really
cons:
- Unorganized for the most part
- Pretty low salaries, but it might be average for this field, I'm not sure

review_title: It is what you make it.
pros: Very smart and funny people, also really good professors. The Professors here are amazing.
cons: People can be very cliquish. Very little Student spirit, which the administration needs to work on. They also need to fix food for non-kosher abiding students.

review_title: Great Environment, Pay cap is a pain though
pros: Great environment, friendly people, definitely willing to help you learn
cons: There are pay and hourly caps on what students can be paid, so that limits your options, even when you could be doing more.

review_title: RA is better than working retail
pros: Flexible work schedule.  You can work from home.  You don't have to deal with customers.
cons: Pay was very low in spite of having a degree from the same university.

review_title: Not a great place to work at
pros: flexible work hours, autonomy, great students, nice campus, great co-workers
cons: Not inclusive as they think they are. The school stands for social justice, yet it is poorly implemented on campus

review_title: Seems to lack perks of other Higher Ed jobs
pros:
Work schedule
Ability to take classes
Colleagues friendly and helpful
cons:
Management was disorganized
Pay too low and not balanced out with typical higher ed perks
Felt highly political

pros: Build long-term relationship with Professors, accumulate research experience, polish up your econometric and quantitative research skills
cons: A lot of extra work, have to multi-task between study and research. Must balance the efforts you put on the research  and GPA

pros: Very collaborative community and gender-balanced faculty, great options for basic science research
cons:
Their program is constantly changing requirements (could be seen as positive or negative)
Typical academic struggles of publish or perish at the will of your boss (PI)
Faculty do gossip

job_title: Master Student Researcher in Waltham, MA
pros: Good place to do research. Traditional style of teaching & training. Don't take students as slaves.
cons: A little far away from Boston. Life is a little tepid. Expense for living is high, as other areas in Great Boston area.

pros: Flexible scheduling- you pick your own shifts, no outside work required, good pay for special shifts
cons: Boring at times, rude students, drunk students

pros: Work with younger students, learn how to advise properly, develop great collaboration skills, and our bosses were great.
cons: Sometimes a bit disorganized and teams did not make deadlines.

review_title: As a TA and RA, professors are very nice
pros: Professors are nice; payments are timely; officers are nice too
cons: Pay was not high; some TAs are not as good as other

review_title: Nice place to study and work
pros: Nice work life balance and the professors are kind and very responsible. All your colleagues are competitive and has strong background.
cons: A little bit far away from the Boston/Cambridge area. Food is not so good.

pros:
Great benefits!  
Many vacation days - Jewish AND American holidays
cons: Annoying people.  It hard to handle such a large group of annoying people

pros: Easy interview process, good pay and very flexible hours overall a very good experience
cons: Cons are a lack of direction and communication and a lot of expectations without communication

review_title: Helping students understand Java one line at a time!
pros: Nice people, flexible hours, good experience
cons: Sometimes gets repetitive, not all teaching assistants are qualified for the job

review_title: Brandeis is awesome for math graduate TAs
pros: I think overall the workload is fairly light for Brandeis TAs. Moreover the management (Becci, Keith, etc) is very helpful and nice.
cons: Nothing I can think of

review_title: Felt like I was in game of thrones
pros: Cafeteria was updated, that was good,
cons: There was a class system between staff, faculty,  grad students,  very political

job_title: Senior Procurement Representative in Waltham, MA
pros: Excellent work-life balance. Opportunities for educational advancement, courses are reimbursed after completion of courses.
cons: Top-heavy management. Micro management. Not everyone has your best interest at heart.

pros:
-Occupies your time outside of classes
-Gain some experience while making some money
-Experience provides you with good interview talking points
cons:
-It's so spaced out, it may be easy to get lost in the crowd
-

pros: The locations is nice comparing with downtown. People don't push you too hard, while you can find a lot of things to work on.
cons: Compensation is not as high as some other places.

pros: I like the university atmosphere.  Most of my colleagues are easy to work with. Generous vacation package.
cons: Though starting salaries are competitive, there is not much of an annual pay raise.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: Great staff and faculty; lots of opportunities to get funding for summer research for students
cons: Your work schedule depends on you and your PI, if you are a student worker.

pros: Strong math department.  Medium/Strong graduate students
cons: Pay is low.  Academics at the bottom of the pyramid are very overworked.

review_title: Everyone is really nice in the office
job_title: Library Resource Management Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: Everyone is extremely nice. You definitely will learn about resource management in a library and how to maintain a library database.
cons: There is not really a con

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Waltham, MA
pros: Great graduate program. Guaranteed funding.
cons: They advertise an average graduation of 5.5 years. I don't know where they get that figure but its not true for the Biology Department alone.

pros: Very intelligent people, decent pay, great work/life balance, free food, and events.
cons: Surround area is boring and the closest city is Boston which can be far if you're taking public transport.

pros: Good Collaborations and Brilliant professors to work for
cons: Brandeis can seem small at times, and somewhat overshadowed by other institutions in the area.

job_title: Library After Hours Monitor in Waltham, MA
pros: You can work at night and have your day to yourself.
cons: You have to keep awake and alert

pros:
Small size
Prestigious: 32nd best in the country
Great access to professors
cons:
No the best location (Waltham, MA)
There could be more to boost school spirit

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Great location - suburbs of Boston
Great education - private school with tons of academic resources
Great working environment - encouraging faculty members
cons: Relatively slow pace, relatively small size

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Brookline, MA
pros: Students are talented and faculty is likewise
cons: Organization is in state of flux

review_title: Great place to do a PhD
job_title: Researcher, PhD Candidate in Waltham, MA
pros: Great atmosphere. Brilliant scientists. Many opportunities to mentor students and teach.
cons: A PhD is rough anywhere. No work life balance at all.

pros:
Great work-life balance
Exellent benefits
Academic benefits are a huge plus!!
cons: Non-profit, so salary earning potential over time is a lot less

job_title: Technical Support Specialist in Waltham, MA
pros: I studied there and worked as part-time technique specialist. People were nice and work was fun.
cons: Not really anything bad for a student job.

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Waltham, MA
pros:
Great atmosphere
Amazing coworkers/bosses
Decent pay
Kind clients
cons:
The school is nowhere near any good restaurants
Inaccessible if you don't live in Waltham (bad public transportation)

job_title: Library and Technology Services, Interlibrary Loan Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: Flexible hours, friendly coworkers, free m&ms
cons: Office holidays and library hours don't always line up, but the hours can be made up.

pros: Intellectual community. Students are smart and engage. Flexibility in schedule.
cons: Lack of systems. Culture does not encourage innovation or systems change.

pros: Mission driven, collaborative motivated bright colleagues
cons: At times direction was unclear but I have heard this is changing

review_title: Great school not great place to work
pros: Working with students and flexible working hours.
cons: bad management, bad pay, and sometimes stressful

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: The staff really cares about you and everyone is extremely nice at the university.
cons: They limit the hours of part time workers

pros: Lots of opportunities for masters students to work part-time jobs on campus
cons: Pay isn't great, but relative to job difficulty

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great opportunity for undergraduates who want a part-time job that is productive for their majors
cons: None thus far - great experience.

pros: Flexible hours, great educational experience while working, good on resume
cons: Work is tedious and boring

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: The staffs here are very nice. They are your big support anytime
cons: no too much to say here

job_title: Campus Police Officer in Waltham, MA
pros: Money is very good as well as time off and benefits
cons: Don't expect much in management backing.

job_title: Head Of Operations in Waltham, MA
pros:
Great Work Place

Great Place to grow
cons: work life balance can be hard for college students

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Waltham, MA
pros: Flexible to my schedule and provide me multiple responsibilities.
cons: Can be mundane and tedious work.

pros: Great professors/students to work with; small and friendly environment
cons: Nothing; Brandeis is a very great environment to work in
